Award.AwardTitle: The Sondrestrom Upper Atmospheric Research Facility: Research, Operation and Coordination
Award.AbstractNarration: This is an award to continue management, operations, and scientific activities in support of the Sondrestrom upper atmosphere research facility located near Kangerlussuaq, on the west coast of Greenland. Activities include all technical aspects concerning the incoherent-scatter (IS) radar, the Rayleigh and resonance lidars, and the all-sky imager, and to provide science, service, education, and leadership of the facility. Other instruments at the site support solid earth, stratospheric, and environmental change research in addition to the physics of solar-terrestrial relationships. The facility management features evolutionary development with further implementation of state-of-the-art radar data acquisition and processing schemes that are becoming practicable with new technology, further advancements in lidar and all-sky imager capabilities, upgrades in telescience capabilities, and improvements to the facility infrastructure that will enable key instrument deployments in the future. To provide an environment that promotes education and training, an educational advisory board, consisting of a group of diversified, education research experts, will determine and develop the most effective way of formulating, implementing, communicating and disseminating information and data to public and educational institutions. Also, a new post-doctoral program will be established to train the future research professionals in the field, and the existing graduate student research experience program will be augmented to increase student involvement. To foster new ideas in upper atmospheric research, facility staff will advance instrumentation to promote scientific discovery, ensure data are of high research quality, and maintain expertise in the related sciences conducted at the facility. Areas of research include the pioneering effort to investigate the response and variability of the high latitude ionosphere from seconds to solar cycles, the exploration of the ionosphere's role in the coupled magnetosphere-ionosphere system, and the deciphering of the myriad processes occurring in the mesosphere/lower thermosphere-ionosphere region. The IS radar will be operated more than 1200 hours per year to respond to the evolving needs of the community, provide flexibility in radar operations to capture space weather events, and make more data available for retrospective analysis, To take advantage of these extensive observations, facility staff will focus on collaborative studies with other existing and planned high-latitude radars. This will pave the way to establishing a high-latitude IS radar consortium to optimize coordinated operations and encourage the exchange of scientific and technical developments among the radar facilities. A new data handling and processing strategy will be implemented to provide ready access to real-time data products, immediate analysis of 20 years of radar data, and assimilation of radar data into physics-based community models. The investigators will also maintain relationships with the Greenland Home Rule Government and Danish Commission for Scientific Research in Greenland to ensure effective management and operation of the facility.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of the project included a number of fundamental tasks that we performed as part of our facility functions: we scheduled, operated, maintained, upgraded, planned, and designed experiments for the radar, lidar, and all-sky imagers; coordinated user visits and provided logistics support; acted as scientific, technical, and logistic liaisons for user experiments; sustained high-quality data products; preserved a comprehensive data library at Menlo Park, California; provided data to the Madrigal database; provided data to any and all requestors; maintained, enhanced, and developed software for acquiring, reducing, and interpreting data; collaborated with scientists; employed highly qualified site personnel; and served as science liaison among the Greenland Self Rule Government, Danish Commission for Scientific Research in Greenland, and the National Science Foundation.

The ISR recorded 12,824 hours of data during this project. All these data have been processed and posted to the Madrigal database, http://isr.sri.com/madrigal. The facility lidars recorded 3,304 hours during this cooperative agreement. These data are available via the project website, http://www.isr.sri.com/instruments/data/arclite/arclite.html. The facility lidars also contributed to studies of the middle atmosphere and are part of a global network contributing data to the international Network for the Detection of Atmospheric Composition Change (NDACC). The two facility all-sky imagers recorded optical data for all dark-sky periods, available at http://transport.sri.com/asicat. Besides the facility instruments, we hosted 22 other scientific systems for external PIs with external funding. Data and results from these co-located instruments are used by the scientists in their own research, education, and outreach activities.

Among the project’s accomplishments are 85 peer-reviewed publications. New insights into trans-polar cap dynamics were achieved by using the search-coil magnetometer on-site in Sondrestrom, combined with instrumentation on Svalbard studying travelling convective vortices, electromagnetic ion-cyclotron wave bursts, and proton precipitation associated with bow-shock instabilities. A new empirical model of Poynting flux was also developed using data from Sondrestrom and the FAST satellite.

We also interacted with facility users, trained researchers and mentored students and early-career scientists in incoherent scatter theory, polar aeronomy, auroral dynamics, and space science. The project supported multiple students through collaborations in the US and abroad, and also supported a post-doctoral research associate. In addition to three PhD dissertations and one Master’s thesis in progress, 21 PhD dissertations and seven Master’s theses used data from the Sondrestrom facility.

The site supervisor and the PI supported several local initiatives at the school in Kangerlussuaq, Greenland. The project supported and was involved with a number of NSF-funded education initiatives, including Joint Science Education Project (JSEP) and PolarTREC. The project supported the annual ISR Student Workshop and other schools and conferences that directly engage undergraduate and graduate scientists and engineers from the US and international institutions on incoherent scatter theory, radar, ionospheric physics, and related topics.

Approximately one-fourth of the 12,824 hours of radar measurements was devoted to a global initiative of world day campaigns, when all 10 of the world’s ISRs run coordinated campaigns. The remaining three-fourths of the radar time was scheduled according to requests from the community. This involved 92 scientists from 51 different institutions. Each of these scientists contributed within their fields, spanning the stratosphere, neutral charge dynamics, electro-dynamics, magnetosphere-ionosphere coupling, high-latitude convection, auroral dynamics, and satellite ground-truthing. To our knowledge, it resulted in 85 peer-reviewed publications and scores of oral presentations and posters at meetings including AGU, CEDAR, and GEM.

In addition to the 92 scientists who requested radar runs at the Sondrestrom radar, a total of 190 students used data from the Sondrestrom facility during the annual ISR schools. In addition to data that users received directly from SRI staff, 156 users downloaded 788,111 datasets from the Madrigal database.

As the project spanned many fields, it impacted aeronomy, magnetospheric physics, auroral physics, and plasma physics. In addition, the facility hosted instruments outside the core fields, including:

- surface particle samplers used in a study of global climate change, and

- a gravimeter used to study the ice mass balance of the Greenland ice sheet. Recent measurements suggested a much faster melt rate than previously measured.

We became more involved in the small Greenlandic community near the radar site, enhancing their public awareness and attitudes toward environmental issues and science and technology in general. By supporting instrumentation that contributes to studies of arctic snow melt and ice mass changes, we have had a positive impact on public awareness and knowledge of climate variability.
